intro: Cedrela herrerae, commonly known as the Mexican cedar, is a tropical tree native to Central America and parts of Mexico. It belongs to the family Meliaceae and is characterized by its straight grain and durable wood, which is highly valued in the timber industry. The plant typically grows in lowland tropical forests and can reach heights of up to 30 meters. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and ovate, while its flowers are small and clustered in panicles. Cedrela herrerae plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, providing shelter and food for various wildlife species.
